snippet.textDisplay:
I am so proud of you and I'm so sorry you are hurting.
I have a complicated relationship with my dad (different reasons but similar since it's based around him never accepting me or showing me the respect I deserve). It took me a long, long time to get to a point where I'd talk about it and process my feelings. It was all so hard. I promise it gets easier from here though.
I hit the point where you seem to be about three years ago. It was one of the most difficult experiences of my life. I'm in such a better place now though. I still wish I could have a healthy relationship with my father (and he recently reached out and is considering what I'd need him to do to mend things) but it doesn't hurt the way it used to. I've moved on to a place where I am open to trying if he recognizes my needs and my worth but I will also be fine if it never happens. I am in a place of peace with all of that and I hope that this means you are on the road to getting to the same point because you deserve that.
Huge hugs through the screen! Thank you for sharing this with all of us who adore you and know that you are not alone.

snippet.textDisplay: Jehovah’s Witnesses are apparently pretty big jerks. As a born again Christian, I am very saddened by your situation. If we think something someone is doing is sinful, that’s not where our focus should ever be. Telling someone I can’t come support you and love because of your sin is like saying God can’t love you because of your sin. But the Bible says the opposite. “But God demonstrates his own love for us in this: While we were still sinners, Christ died for us.” But I do want to pose the same advice to you as I would give your dad: Shaming someone if they do have a wrong attitude will not change their attitude, only love can motivate someone to want to be better. Only love has that power.

snippet.textDisplay: Hannah, so much love and respect to you for standing up. My former church barred my father from attending my wedding and I went ahead with it anyway and I regret that to this day 25 years later. The church I was a part of tells people that families can be together forever but then does things to split people up, ESPECIALLY from lgbtq+ children. I am so sorry that this is happening in your life. This does not define you and I want to share that I see you as one of the best humans there are, you have so much to be proud of in yourself and mostly the fact that you spread love to fellow humans and you give people a reason to laugh. Please know that you are loved and valued.

snippet.textDisplay: Hannah, I have watched your channel for several years. I've never commented but I've always admired you. You're not afraid to be you. It is something that I am slowly learning how to do. This video shows me that you are an amazing, strong, beautiful human being and it is your dad and stepmom who are truly missing out on the opportunity to have a relationship with one of the most amazing people I've ever encountered. Surround yourself with your chosen family (this includes your mom, I believe that birth family CAN be included in chosen family but never should be mandatory) and let the toxic people go. I know this isnt an easy task but making this video was the first step and the most difficult step. We love you Hannah, stay strong and most of all CELEBRATE your love with Ella, because that is what truly matters.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm in the same boat, honey. My dad hasn't been in my life for years, he doesn't even know I'm out. I grew up Mormon, which is also a cult, and led to me losing my entire extended family because I don't believe in it anymore, and they can't interact with people who reject the "truth." It's okay to still need him. You're his child--he's supposed to protect and love you. That hurt never goes away. I'm sorry you're hurting during what's supposed to be one of the most joyous times of your life. Please know that it's okay to take time to process your feelings. It's okay to feel however you feel. We all love you very much, and you've given us so much. We're here to listen and support you whenever you need us. I love you, and I'm so excited for you and Ella!

snippet.textDisplay: Hannah, seeing you so upset breaks my heart. I will never understand how any parent can act this way toward their own child. The amount of courage you have shown by posting this is inspiring. My sister is part of the LGBTQ+ community and I’m so thankful that courageous and inspiring people like you exist that speak their truth even though it can be incredibly difficult. I hope that she sees this and feels inspired by you. Thank you for sharing this video with us. You are absolutely right, sweetheart! You have NOTHING to be ashamed of. You’re a wonderful human being and the love between you and Ella is so beautiful to see. You and Ella are an example of what true love really is. I hope that you always see just how beautiful, strong, and capable you truly are. Keep sharing your wedding with pride, sweetheart! You have sooo many people who love and care about you and your well-being. Take care, Hannah. Sending you and Ella so much love from Toronto, Ontario. Big hugs to you, lovely!

snippet.textDisplay:
I totally understand that irrational disappointment. My father has chosen his new family over me over and over (including kicking ME out of the house when his wife beat me with a ruler). I finally had to cut them from my life after finding out some things about my brothers, from my grandfather (should have been my parents), and then finding out they dont even know my son's name, or how old he was. I was still so damn disappointed.


Anyway... Long story short. I have to keep reminding myself (and you should too); family isn't about blood. Family is about those who love you, care for you and are there for you.

So plan your wedding with a smile on your face and just keep looking ahead. Even though it will be hard.

I wish I was brave enough to stand up for myself like you've done here. You're brave and amazing, and this inspires me. We are not unworthy of love and respect. Sending hugs ❤❤ thank you for sharing!

snippet.textDisplay:
My dad’s a fundamentalist and he’s repeatedly made the same choice. He’s already said he and my step-mom won’t be attending any wedding I have in the future. I’m not allowed to sleep in my dad’s home (my old room) when i come to town. My siblings ignore the choices my dad makes because he’s a GREAT dad to them.
I always leave the door open for him to come into my life, and he’s always let me down. But I will continue to leave that door open for now; and honestly, I don’t know any other way to be—because he’s my dad and I’ll always want him around.

But my mom left the Kingdom Hall when I came out and never looked back.

This reality is literally a huge hear of mine because I know it’s inevitable. And Thank you so much for expressing this so clearly. Sending you all the love and happiness on your wedding.

snippet.textDisplay: Your Dad will always choose "the organization" over you. He is brainwashed. He is acting out of fear. His own biological drive to love you as his offspring has been overridden by fear. I am so happy your mother left and kept your sister and you safe from complete mind control. Your comment about being "one person" really hit home. I never felt like myself while living under my father's roof. None of my "choices" were my own. I started to heal faster than ever the last couple years  when I chose to go no contact with my entire family. I was raised by third generation JWs. Also, the Reddit thread r/exJW has been very helpful. For anyone reading this and seeking professional help. Look for a therapist or mental health professional who specializes in leaving cults. Because speaking to friends isn't always enough. They cannot begin to understand how it affects EVERY facet of your life.  You are strong and loving and creative and humble and intelligent. Thank you so much for sharing this so publicly in all it's rawness!

snippet.textDisplay:
I am the father of 2 loving adults and a loving teenager and your story breaks my heart. A child should never have to question what they are worth to their parents. Regardless of religion, morals, or biases, a parent's responsibility is to provide unconditional love. Are parents perfect? Nothing is perfect, and we all make mistakes, and all parents should hope that their children grow beyond our mistakes and not be burdened by them as chains.
You may not have the father you want or deserve, but you are going to make an amazing parent if you choose to be one. Yosemite is beautiful only because it spent millions of years being torn down. You are a beautiful, intelligent, courageous person. I'm telling you right now, though you are not my child, I am very Very proud of you. I wish you happiness and compassion in your marriage, and in your sure-to-be amazing life.

snippet.textDisplay: I have been through this...in a straight wedding..my father refused to come to our wedding because he is a christian and we had a civil ceremony. snippet.textDisplay:
So understand how you feel. My parents initially did not want to come to my wedding either because they too are JWs. However, I also told my dad that when our wedding guests and my in-laws would ask why my parents were not at the wedding I would have not hidden the reasons or make excuses for them so they should think long and hard to the kind of "witnessing" they would have been indirectly giving and how all those people would have reacted the next time a witness knocked on their door. This conversation happened 4 months before our wedding. Six days before the wedding, they texted me saying they had considered it and decided to come.
By then, I honestly did not care for me whether they'd come or not, we live in different countries anyway, I'm used to not seeing them, but I was happy for them as they would have been missing a huge day in the life of their only child. Turned out they had the time of their lives. So, I know it's cliché, but it is truly your dad's loss. Keep your head high. ❤️

snippet.textDisplay:
Hanna,

You are loved by tens of thousands of people, just counting your followers, and by countless others who watch but don’t subscribe, not to mention all the other social media platforms.

You have changed peoples’ lives for the better and will continue to do so. The fact that SO many people care about you and hurt for you is testament to what a GOOD and WONDERFUL person you are!

Now for the bad news, in no particular order...

Your father is a cult member.
Your father is a bad parent.
Your father is a bad person.
Your father is a disgrace.
Your father is nothing more than a sperm donor.

The fact that he can’t celebrate your happiness is PROOF of his worthlessness.

I know it hurts. I know you want his approval, but his cult bonds are stronger than his love for you.

You need to recognize, embrace, and take strength from the fact that YOU are good to the core and loved by SO many others. That’s a HUGE deal! The fact that you bring happiness to so many people and THEY in turn wish love and happiness upon you, should bring you great pride. Pride that is MUCH MORE important than validation from some worthless religious loser. What good does HE bring to anyone’s life?

Ella loves you!
You mom loves you!
I love you!
My hubby loves you!

What the sperm donor thinks is irrelevant.
HE brings nothing positive to the table.

Love and hugs and hope to see you around!

❤️ Dave & Todd

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who chooses to follow Christ with my life, I want to apologize on behalf of your dad for not at all understanding what it means to take the first and second commandments seriously to love God, then love others as you love yourself. You're his child and he's unfortunately making the wrong choice in this situation. It would be one thing if he just expressed how he disagrees with the decisions you make in life, but the fact that he's choosing a religion over a relationship with you ENTIRELY is not okay. You're an adult and can make your own choices whether he agrees with them or not & he needs to respect that. A Christian friend of mine made the same choice about going to her sister's gay wedding for basically the same reasons and I never agreed with her then either. I would never encourage you to give up on your relationship with your dad, but being that he's the parent, it's his responsibility to make things right at this point and not yours. It may be, based on what you've already said, that the best thing is to let him go and to let it be. I will make sure to keep your family in my prayers Hannah. I'm so sorry this has to be a part of your story <3

snippet.textDisplay: Hannah, I’m in the same situation. My family is Jehovah’s Witness, and I am gay. They know, it’s kind of obvious, but we’ve never talked about it before and I live in the constant fear that all of a sudden they will come to me asking questions about my sexuality and eventually kick me out of the house and distance themselves from me. I am also un-baptized and I do have a good group of friends that support me and love me; but no matter how many good people I surround myself with it will never be equal to the relationship that I want with my parents. It really is the hardest thing that I’ve ever had to deal with. Since I was around 12, and realized that I was gay and was aware of my situation, I fell into a deep depression. I self harmed for years and thought about/planned my suicide more times than I can remember. Thankfully now I’m doing somewhat better, mental health wise. I’ve been in therapy for over a year now and talking medication for my depression for about the same amount of time. My therapist has been a huge help when I came to dealing with the existentialism surrounding my family. After telling him about what it’s like growing up as a Jehovah’s Witness, and gay, he said that he was shocked that I was doing so well for someone who had gone through so much trauma as a young person. Seeing people like you on YouTube, just being yourself without apology has definitely been very inspirational for me growing up. It pains me to see that you went through, and are still going through, the same thing that I am; but it does make me feel stronger in some sort of way. You keep showing me how important it is to be myself, cheesy as it sounds. So I just want to thank you for everything you do for the community, even if it is just making me laugh for a few minutes. ❤️❤️❤️
snippet.textOriginal: Hannah, I’m in the same situation. My family is Jehovah’s Witness, and I am gay. They know, it’s kind of obvious, but we’ve never talked about it before and I live in the constant fear that all of a sudden they will come to me asking questions about my sexuality and eventually kick me out of the house and distance themselves from me. I am also un-baptized and I do have a good group of friends that support me and love me; but no matter how many good people I surround myself with it will never be equal to the relationship that I want with my parents. It really is the hardest thing that I’ve ever had to deal with. Since I was around 12, and realized that I was gay and was aware of my situation, I fell into a deep depression. I self harmed for years and thought about/planned my suicide more times than I can remember. Thankfully now I’m doing somewhat better, mental health wise. I’ve been in therapy for over a year now and talking medication for my depression for about the same amount of time. My therapist has been a huge help when I came to dealing with the existentialism surrounding my family. snippet.textDisplay: I deeply deeply respect you. I empathize. I feel you. You have NOTHING to be ashamed of. You are right. You are worthy of ALL unconditional love. You are worthy of having a father who unconditionally loves you and accepts you. You are loving, you are kind, you are empathetic. You are sincere. You are honest. You are mighty. You are allowed to be vulnerable, and your power is deep and profound. We see you. We hear you. We support you, this community and anyone who has been so lucky to see you. Organized religion and cults, I feel this pain. I feel it. And I know, you and I and so many in our generation are using our honest experiences to help others be free. You are doing that by posting this video. I’m so proud of you. I am so GRATEFUL for you. We will celebrate you. We can’t fill the space your father refuses to allow himself to occupy, a role you deserve to have in your life, father. But we can be something more, something expansive, a community, a great big community of love, of people who get shivers thinking of you because our bodies remember our own trauma, how to feels to be treated how you are treated by your dad, we feel your pain because many of us also know it. And you are not alone in your suffering, sweet one. We, people throughout the world, hear you. And we will celebrate you and your LOVE for your partner every step of the way. We love you.

snippet.textDisplay: Oh, this is so, so, hurtful. Grief is the right word. But there are family you are born to and family you choose. I want to share one piece of advice. When it comes time for your day, they tell you whatever is done is done, and what’s not is not. When you wake up that morning and are getting ready, you are done planning and it is time to make the most out of this day that you have planned so much for, that you have tried to make a dream of a day. Sometimes the cake or flowers don’t show up. This time... it’s your father. It sucks so much, but you deserve this day, and as long as he sounds like he would make it worse, you are more likely to have one of the best days of your life. Thank you for sharing this information. I thought religion was about bringing people together, not destroying family relationships. All the good vibes I can spare go to you. ❤️

snippet.textDisplay: I can’t even begin to say how heartbreaking this is. Hannah, I’m so sorry. I know how it is to be disappointed by someone doing exactly what you expect of them. There’s nothing wrong with you being upset by that, because through all the crap he’s still your dad, he’s not some random person. There’s nothing wrong with hoping that he could surprise you, even though you knew he wouldn’t and excepted it. It’s normal to want your dad at your wedding, and it’s normal to want to see your baby girl happy and want to walk her down the isle. He’s the odd one out, not you, and you don’t deserve it. You are a wonderful, beautiful ray of sunshine that makes so many people happier everyday. One day, he will regret this, and that will be on him to live with. snippet.textDisplay: I'm in a relationship with a Taiwanese man. My father had been negative about our relationship from the beginning but when I was going to travel to China with him for a year, my father was even more upset. It felt like we could work on it but when I decided to stay for another year, he emailed me to say he is disowning me. He said he wasn't going to watch me mess up my life and then said derogatory things about my partner. It's been three years and it still hurts. It's heartbreaking that he decided that my own choice to live a life that is amazing and fulfilling and happy, wasn't valued more than what he believes was the right path for me.  I'm sorry you're also hurting. I hope everyone else around you continues to surround you with love because you deserve it 💗
